It led to a peculiar temporary situation where people suspected of pro-Nazi activity or those who had abused positions of authority lived next to 850 liberated individuals in the camp. The camp was briefly a training base for KNIL soldiers leaving to fight in Indonesia against the revolution of independence. Interestingly, camp Westerbork would see the aftermath of this as on 4th July, 1950, the first Indonesian Dutch repatriates arrived to shelter themselves from retalliations. Around Christmas 1950, the camp had 1 050 inhabitants. They lived in two large barracks near the entrance of the camp. One barrack was for families, the other for single people and older children. The Schattenberg remained isolated and the Moluccan community gradually found work and mostly moved out from the accommodation. The Schattenberg was demolished in 1971 the only remaining visible reference ot the past was the National Monument which had been unveiled on 4th May, 1970.

page_blocks.text: In 2017, Sieg Maandag, a survivor from Bergen Belsen, passed away. He reminded public opinion not of an individual story of survival, but of the uncomfortable and harrowing presence that images of war have been ever since. In April 1945, he fell under the photographic gaze of British photojournalist George Rodger, who was, as most at the time, looking to convey what seemed to be all of a sudden the hidden tragedies of the Nazi camp system. Maandag, an eight-year-old boy, was, in that famous picture, looking rather confused in the opposite direction of a road lined with corpses.(1) For a long time, Maandag was almost synonymous to an image of innocence lost, of many generations having to deal and live with the reality of the war as the documentary evidence, those who had survived and were telling their stories and demanding people not to turn a blind eye were increasing. Roger’s very career testified to these issues: he set up Magnum, together with Robert Capa, another man shaped by war, and yet he refused to work in conflict zones, conflicted about the ethics of this documentation. Paradoxically, two years after Maandag’s death, in 2019, when the same picture was used in an exhibition in Amsterdam, it became evident that Maandag’s picture in Life magazine in 1945 had been indeed difficult for the American and worldwide public. The dead, arguably those who died because of the deadly typhus epidemics during the last days of the camp and in the first weeks after liberation, had been airbrushed. The debate focused on this selective truth of war which has been reproduced in the last seven decades, but it equally says something about the way images of war are used, disused and selectively become the symbol of conflict.

In the very least, the fact that a form of documentation, albeit the only such glimpse into a daily life of the camp, is turned into an object of heritage is an interesting issue. In 2017, the Westerbork movie, the only material filmed in the concentration camps, became UNESCO world heritage. It a sense, this change not only speaks about the awareness given to camps and to war in the age of “regret” but also that traces and representations of camps become, as Timothy Mitchell argues, images that do, and that they mobilize an understanding of history, a new way of finding direct relevance in this.

Indeed, as heritage, the imagery of war and conflict have been central less to the remembrance of war and more so the precaution against war, a discourse of prevention which places imagery of war at the intersection of a didactic, social meaning of war. It was in fact, something happening not only in the documentary interest of people like Rodger. The Allied photography during the war was a strong presence in press and footage and newsreel on the exploits on the front, from newsreel to news. The mobilization of this type of images during the war was to present the war as a heroic exploit against the Nazis but also a motivation of the extensive mobilization of effort. The Soviet press at the time was equally covering the extensive “antifascist” campaign, as perhaps best illustrates the famous “Raising a Flag over the Reichstag” by Yevgeny Khaldei (3). The heroism of war was synonymous, in this context, with the documentation and the unravelling of the power to deceive of the defeated enemies.

Whether that was indeed the situation during the war is a more nuanced question. The camps, in particular, were meant to be hidden, the very notion of camp implies an isolation and disenfranchisement of the individual, but they were, by no means, really invisible. Reports from the camp circulated through Europe all through the 5 years. The Polish Jan Karksi spoke about the inferno in occupied Poland as soon as 1940 as a matter of international affairs with the British, French and Soviet governments. The Vrba Wetzel report with testimonies smuggled out of Auschwitz kept headlines in 1943 all through Europe. The suffering of the Jews in camps was known.

But Allied phototography was equally important to the situation post-war. The “forced confrontations” imposed by the Allies to members of the communities around dictated, of sorts, the image and the use of images of atrocity, of death and the violent deaths suffered in the war. Images of these moments were perhaps as powerful as the images of bodies themselves.(6)

But the case of Roger’s retouching suggests however that images of atrocity have been  difficult to debate even as the war was going on or ending. This debate, about the ethics of responsibility, whether this owes primarily to the dignity of the victim, or on the contrary, to the ethics of social knowledge about war and conflict in general continues today. The extent to which such images were to the displayed is a constant question for memorials and museums, for instance: does too much exposure desensitize the viewer? Does the viewer engage in a voyeuristic gesture, inevitably, when in contact with such images and hence diminish both their effect and undercut the very purpose of their purpose for the victim?
